item.title: Ticket #1667 (Comment moderation should apply to registered users also!!) updated
item.dc:creator: kidaz
item.description: Version, Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #1667 (Comment moderation should apply to registered users also!!) created
item.dc:creator: kidaz
item.description:
Assuming WP version 1.5.2 Comment moderation should apply to registered users also. (This has nothing to do with SPAM)

From an administrator account options->discussion

"Before a comment appears:

  • An administrator must approve the comment (regardless of any matches below)"

This described functionality does not exist at present, despite being implied.

In reality it only applies to non-logged-in users. It should apply to logged-in, that is registered users also.

The assumption that registered users will always be trustworthy is a weak one. As such, efforts should be made to cater for malicious, but registered users.

We are targeting comments that are uncatchable by SPAM filters, since comments can be offensive without being crude. Perhaps an unwelcome neo-Nazi may comment,

"Black people are all evil".

This has no swearing, but is extremely offensive/inappropriate. And no company/institution/personal blog, would want this in all liklihood.

Mechanism I propose that there should be a mechanism to give admins the option to direct comments from all users to the moderation queue. Specifically, I suggest that there be a checkbox to the effect of "Apply these restrictions to registered users also"

Or even better, controls for specific user levels. I.e. Can comments go live immediately? Levels 1-4 no, and 5-10 yes. The pivot point, need only be entered by the admins.

Benefits:

Professionalism: WP websites can always have unoffensive and appropriate comments. Since users comments reflect the organisation, from a customers point of view.

Disadvantages

More work: Admins must check all comments when this is the case. However it is just an option, and should be able to be turned off.

item.title:
Ticket #1666 (unnecessary

tag added at beginning of some posts (kills XHTML 1.1 ...) updated
item.dc:creator: seth
item.description:
I should mention that oftentimes the problem manifests itself as a </p> at the end without an opening <p> as well... here's an example. 

<p> Okay kids, this guy did EVERYTHING right.(20:38:56) Nhlmaster28: Hey this is chaingang28 from the invisionfree forum and since your admin I was wondering if you could validate my account? </p>
<blockquote>(20:39:10) Seth: sure, what is your e-mail address<br />
   (20:39:18) Nhlmaster28: Nhlmaster28 at aol.com<br />
   (20:39:46) Seth: validated :) have a good night<br />
   (20:39:51) Nhlmaster28: thanks you too </blockquote>
<ul>
<li>He identified himself immediately, and stated his request, all in the first message</li>
<li>No "hey" or "yt?" messages</li>
<li>His request was not for support, it was for something related to the forums, of which I am the admin</li>
<li>He was nice about it</li>
  </ul>
  I salute you, Mr. Nhlmaster28; may others learn from your example :)

Turns into: 

						<p> Okay kids, this guy did EVERYTHING right.(20:38:56) Nhlmaster28: Hey this is chaingang28 from the invisionfree forum and since your admin I was wondering if you could validate my account? </p>
	<blockquote><p>(20:39:10) Seth: sure, what is your e-mail address<br />   (20:39:18) Nhlmaster28: Nhlmaster28 at aol.com<br />   (20:39:46) Seth: validated <img src='http://sethkinast.com/blog/wp-includes/images/smilies/happy.png' alt=':)' class='wp-smiley' />  have a good night<br />   (20:39:51) Nhlmaster28: thanks you too </p></blockquote>
	<ul>
<li>He identified himself immediately, and stated his request, all in the first message</li>
	<li>No “hey” or “yt?” messages</li>
	<li>His request was not for support, it was for something related to the forums, of which I am the admin</li>
	<li>He was nice about it</li>
  </ul>
  I salute you, Mr. Nhlmaster28; may others learn from your example <img src='http://sethkinast.com/blog/wp-includes/images/smilies/happy.png' alt=':)' class='wp-smiley' />
</p>

Notice the extra </p> at the end of this post for no apparent reason! :(

item.title:
Ticket #1666 (unnecessary

tag added at beginning of some posts (kills XHTML 1.1 ...) created
item.dc:creator: seth
item.description: I start many posts with a <blockquote> of cited material. WordPress attempts to add a <p> tag inside the <blockquote>, but then never closes the <p>. This causes my XHTML 1.1 pages to break. I haven't figured out a suitable workaround other than not starting my posts with a <div> or <blockquote>.

item.title: Ticket #1656 (Need more customization of more-link markup) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Laura, This is an issue I've also grappled with. I eventually settled upon a regex filter to look for the "read more" link and then reformat it. Here is my code: 

add_filter('the_content', 'txfx_show_more_content', 50);
function txfx_show_more_content($text) {
// %linkstart% symbolizes the opening <a href=""> tag for the entry
// you should manually close the link with </a> in your replacement
$replacement = 	'<p class="read-more">' . "\n" . '%linkstart%' . 'Read the rest »</a>' . "\n" . '</p>';
$site = str_replace('/', '\/', str_replace('.', '\.', get_bloginfo('url'))) . '\/';
$replacement = str_replace('%linkstart%', '$1', $replacement);
$text = preg_replace('/(<a href="' . $site . '.*?#more-.*?">)\(more...\)<\/a>/', $replacement, $text);
return $text;
}

Note that it looks for (more...), which is the default text for the_content()... so you have to make sure your template doesn't pass a parameter to the_content(), or it won't work. Other than that, just change the $replacement string, using %linkstart% to designate where <a href="[your permalink]"> goes.

Hope this helps.

item.title: Ticket #1564 (More and NextPage buttons missing in WYSI editor (patch)) reopened
item.dc:creator: JasonV
item.description:
"The comments are displayed graphically in the editor, but are stored as html comments upon output or when editing the html directly."

This does not seem to function correctly, because the image tags for the graphic display remain in the HTML and are NOT replaced by the WP HTML comments.
